and the acute coronary syndrome.

there are 90,000 episodes of chest pain

54.text:

as much as $17.9 billion a year.

1474.text:
do suggest that the gold bar,
the best standard is the PCI.

1478.text:
And if there's an algorithm
at the National Heart Foundation...

1481.text: So it's getting a helicopter in...

1483.text:
Helicopter, ambulance,
lights and sirens going down

1487.text:
But in my redneck of the woods,
Orbost has gotta be six hours away

1492.text:
from a tertiary facility
that can do something there.

1494.text:
That's a long time to wait
to see if you can get them down there

1497.text:
when doing fibrinolysis is going to be
a much better option for them.

1500.text:
You've done too much damage if you
sit there and wait. So it's a call...

1504.text:
What are you looking for?
What do they call it?

1506.text:
What are you looking for
for the thrombolysis

1508.text: to say, 'Well, we're in control here.

1510.text:
You don't have to actually
go to Melbourne.'

1513.text:
I think if you can't make a decision
in that first 30 minutes

1516.text:
and you can't find someone
to pick this patient up,

1518.text: and that's going to be the thing...

1520.text:
South Australia,
we were talking earlier,

1522.text:
has much better developed networks
than we have

1524.text: and they have a system and protocols

1525.text:
and they're discussing it with their
tertiary hospitals from the go-get.

1530.text:
In Victoria,
that doesn't exist like that.

1532.text:
Sometimes it's a cat-and-mouse game
trying to find a facility

1535.text:
to actually pick them up -
weekends, 3:00 in the morning,

1538.text:
not everybody's willing to say, 'This
person is someone that I want to do it.'

1542.text:
'I've got an 89-year-old lady here.'
'Nah, don't want to.'

1546.text:
And so we have to
make a decision quickly

1548.text: which way we're going to go.

1550.text: And what are you looking for?

1552.text:
Well, what we're looking for...
Sue's point is well made.

1557.text:
we've had a very enthusiastic
network developed

1559.text:
where 24/7 at two minutes,
I can get any cardiologist

1563.text:
like Derek, on the phone to advise
what I'm doing with the patient.

1567.text:
So it's a joint management
of the patient

1569.text: on the criteria which we've discussed.

1571.text: Patients need to be treated then.

1573.text:
There needs to be
a management plan constructed,

1575.text:
which could include urgent transport
to Adelaide,

1577.text:
even for rescue PCI after thrombolysis
or for primary PCI.

1582.text: And that's where I'm getting to.

1585.text:
a reduction in the ST elevation
and chest pain going?

1587.text: You would like to see that.

1591.text:
in which case you could assume that
there has been a revascularisation

1594.text:
and although that person should then
have interventional assessment,

1598.text:
it isn't as urgent as needing to go down
for the next two hours,

1602.text:
so I would then ring iCCnet
and someone like Derek would agree,

1607.text:
and then say, 'Fine. I'll organise
the bed and transport for tomorrow

1610.text: or the next day,' and that happens.

1613.text:
If someone comes in
who's urgently unwell

1615.text: and needs to go down straightaway,

1618.text:
I'll ring the same number,
the same advice, we discuss it,

1622.text:
and Derek, again, will organise the bed
and hospital and transport at that time

1627.text:
and a helicopter and everything,
and the patients go down.

1632.text:
Let's take some questions -
Marisa Pilla in Cairns.

1635.text:
'I've read that using high dose lipid
lowering after acute coronary syndromes

1640.text:
gives worse outcomes, is this true?'
We covered that.

1643.text:
Certainly, it's not true.
This was formerly studied in a study

1650.text:
I've got a mental blank
on which one it's called.

1652.text:
The PROVE-IT study used a weaker
versus a stronger lipid-lowering agent

1658.text:
and those who actually had
a stronger strategy

1662.text:
had a lower rate of recurrent myocardial
infarction and death as well as stroke.

1667.text:
So that data
has never been validated in...

1673.text: It's been proven to be wrong, basically.

1675.text:
And another question,
'Is it common now for patients

1678.text: to come out on clopidogrel plus aspirin

1680.text:
and if so, is that due to concerns
about aspirin resistance?'

1684.text:
Aspirin resistance is an interesting
and difficult to define phenomenon

1690.text:
but that's true, the data
is that patients who receive

1694.text:
aspirin and clopidogrel have a lower
rate of recurrent myocardial infarction,

1702.text:
And so, some people have defined
aspirin resistance

1706.text:
as people who have an event
while taking aspirin.

1708.text:
There are many subclinical
or laboratory definitions of this.

1714.text:
From a functional level or a practical
level in the clinical practice,

1719.text:
we know plaque is active in the first
6 to 12 months after an infarct

1726.text:
and dual antiplatelet therapy is clearly
associated with reduced events.

1731.text:
A nurse in rural Queensland asks,
'Are there contraindications

1735.text:
to giving thrombolysis
in Indigenous populations?'

1738.text:
This was probably a reference
to streptokinase

1742.text: which was the original one used

1743.text:
and because of the high incidence
of streptococcal infections

1751.text: and certainly if you gave it to someone,

1753.text:
you couldn't give it again within
12 months in a general population

1757.text:
and the main benefit also
was it was cheap.

1760.text:
It cost about $200 or $300
as opposed to roughly $2,000 a dose.

1764.text:
The cheapness has been outweighed
by the problems and its inefficiency

1769.text:
and so it's not now used
but the other...

1775.text: Thrombolytic agents are the way to go.

1778.text:
And, 'Are there any incidences
where ST elevation

1780.text:
would be treated conservatively
in a remote community?'

1783.text: What do you think about that, Barry?

1787.text: In other words, not much done.

1789.text: I think, you know, given the...

1796.text: having a high chronic disease at low age

1799.text:
and generally most of them
have comorbidities,

1802.text:
I think they're automatically
in a high risk category

1810.text:
Do you get much resistance
to people going?

1815.text:
We get resistance of people wanting
to go to the clinic in the first place

1818.text:
because they're not sure
the cause of the chest pain

1820.text: but when they do turn up,

1824.text:
there is resistance from people
wanting to leave the community

1828.text: and go down to the larger cities.

1830.text:
Because usually it has to happen
really quick, it's sudden

1832.text:
and they want to talk to their families
and that sort of thing.

1835.text:
And any techniques for cajoling them
to make the move?

1840.text:
I reckon just be straightforward
and be direct, just say it like it is.

1847.text:
Another question here from
the same nurse in rural Queensland.

1850.text:
- 'How reliable are STAT troponin kits?'
- Oh, they're highly reliable.

1854.text:
They've continued to evolve. We've had
troponins now for over ten years.

1857.text:
And the assays have moved on
to the fourth and fifth generations

1861.text: and the assays themselves are excellent.

1864.text:
There is a very low rate
of false positives

1866.text:
and a very low rate of, obviously,
false negatives.

1868.text:
So they are... The point of care tests
have evolved, I think,

1872.text:
to become a real standard of care
and something we can base on.

1875.text:
And we've got a graph here showing the
success following troponin introduction.

1880.text:
In fact, I was just going to say
the troponin mechanism we use

1883.text:
is exactly the same quality standards
of a laboratory

1888.text:
so there's no benefit in having
to send it away to a laboratory

1892.text:
But a few years ago,
it was looked at in South Australia

1895.text:
and realised that there was
roughly twice the mortalities

1898.text:
of in-hospital patients with acute
coronary syndrome in country beds

1902.text:
as opposed to
city metropolitan-based beds.

1905.text:
A program evolved, focused
around having troponin on site,

1910.text:
a correct methodology
for assessing and interpreting that,

1913.text:
supported cardiology intervention
as we've discussed on the phone...

1918.text:
NORMAN: Let's look at the graphic,
there's a graphic to go with that.

1921.text:
I hope the graphic will point out
that the coronary deaths now

1924.text: have come back to exactly the same

1927.text:
with the evolution from '97
through to '05,

1932.text:
the red line has now come down
to meet the blue line

1935.text: which is the metropolitan death rate

1938.text:
of patients in-hospital with
acute coronary syndrome.

1941.text:
And this has all evolved
from an integrated approach

1944.text:
dealing with troponin,
correct ECG assessment,

1956.text:
and that's the outcome,
which is nice to see.

1958.text:
NORMAN:
And that's South Australian data?

1962.text:
- That's happened in other States?
SUE: We're working towards it.

1966.text:
Another question by a general
practitioner in rural Victoria -

1969.text:
'How effective is oxygen administration
in an acute cardiac event?'

1972.text: Seems to be given to everybody. Sue?

1974.text:
Absolutely, I mean,
from the point of view that

1976.text:
that's probably the first thing
the patient receives

1979.text: is the oxygen when they come in.

1980.text:
NORMAN: Does that make the nurse
feel better or the patient?

1983.text:
It makes the patient feel better,
it makes everybody feel better.

1986.text: The issue is you're having chest pain

1988.text:
because there's not enough oxygen
going to your myocardium.

1991.text: Oxygen obviously has a role to play.

1993.text:
I see an evidence-based smile
on Professor Chew's face.

1999.text:
It has never been studied thoroughly
in acute coronary syndrome setting

2003.text:
and I did notice recently looking at
the NICE recommendations

2009.text:
NORMAN: This is the American...
- The UK recommendation.

2012.text:
They've watered down
their recommendation for oxygen.

2014.text:
NORMAN: They just can't afford it.
- Exactly.

2018.text:
PETER: The amount of smokers
they face, the place will blow up.

2022.text: NORMAN: So it may work, it may not.

2024.text:
Well, I've certainly witnessed,
and I'm sure everybody else has,

2027.text:
the patient that's been
in your department

2031.text:
but just the pain starts to tickle back
again, they're...

2033.text:
What does oxygen do
to coronary arteries?

2036.text:
It actually causes vasodilation
of your coronary vessels.

2039.text:
NORMAN: That's a relief.
- Yeah, so...

2040.text:
NORMAN: You're not doing any harm.
- Certainly not.

2043.text: Let's go to our first case study.

2046.text:
he's overweight,
he's a retired policeman.

2048.text:
He's actually got a history
of coronary artery disease,

2053.text: he's got a leg ulcer in his right leg.

2056.text: He's on a fair number of medications -

2059.text:
he's on aspirin,
he's on anti-hypertensives,

2061.text:
he's on oral hypoglycaemics
and on a statin.

2063.text:
He comes to a remote health clinic
to see you, Sue,

2066.text:
with central discomfort
going up to his jaw.

2070.text: It started on his morning stroll

2072.text:
and it was relieved with GTN
but it's come back.

2076.text: SUE: And so, he's come back in the door,

2078.text:
we're hoping that as he comes
in the door, oxygen, weigh them.

2082.text:
If you can just get someone to step
on a set of scales

2085.text:
as you're getting them onto a bed,
solves a lot of problems later on.

2088.text:
Aspirin, up on there and ECG,
cardiac monitoring.

2092.text:
NORMAN: Weighing them because
your dose of thrombolysis...

2097.text:
and all those doses
are weight-calculated

2100.text:
so that 30 seconds that they spend
on the scales

2103.text: makes a big difference later on.

2105.text:
But, yeah, up there, IV access, ECG.
Take your ECG and have a look.

2108.text:
This guy has got
a lot of risk factors there.

2110.text:
He ticks all the boxes
that we spoke about before

2113.text:
and so you've got to assume
that this gentleman has got

2116.text:
some degree of acute coronary syndrome
going on there.

2118.text: NORMAN: Let's have a look at his ECG.

2126.text: NORMAN: So, he's got a flipped T-wave.

2128.text:
SUE: Yep, inverted T-waves
going on there.

2131.text:
DEREK: This gentleman's potentially
having an angiogram

2133.text:
much like the one
we've shown you already, actually.

2136.text:
We've got changes in most of his
coronary vascular territories there

2141.text: so he is at increased risk.

2143.text:
I would be at pains to point out,
though,

2145.text:
that whenever we assess patients
with chest pain, I wonder two things -

2150.text: one is does the patient have the disease

2152.text: and two, is that disease symptomatic?

2153.text:
And in this gentleman,
being a diabetic with leg ulcers,

2157.text: we know that he has the same risk

2159.text:
as a person who's already had
an acute myocardial infarct.

2163.text:
- So, I would treat him...
NORMAN: It's as high as you can get.

2166.text:
I would treat him as if
he already has the disease

2168.text: and with the ECG now, he certainly...

2170.text:
I suspect that's symptomatic
as we speak.

2173.text:
NORMAN: But you can't give thrombolysis
on that basis?

2176.text:
DEREK: Certainly not,
there's not sufficient ST elevation,

2178.text:
there is certainly change
suggestive of ischaemia

2181.text:
but not ST elevation sufficient
for thrombolysis based on that.

2184.text: NORMAN: So, you do your troponins.

2188.text:
If they're normal,
we're going to still monitor serial...

2190.text:
Once again, we're going to do serial
troponins we talked about before.

2194.text:
Does he become pain-free?
Can we control the pain?

2196.text:
You're going to manage that patient
depending on what happens after...

2200.text: NORMAN: And if the pain goes away?

2201.text:
Pain goes away,
repeat the troponin's, pain-free.

2204.text: Pain goes away, your GP, physician...

2207.text:
The pain goes away and the troponins
go up, what do you do next?

2210.text: Then we're looking at a non-STEMI.

2211.text:
So we know then that we've actually got
myocardial damage

2214.text:
so we've got to actually look at some
aggressive medication therapy.

2220.text:
We talked before about clopidogrel,
enoxaparin

2226.text:
Even so, his chances of ventricular
fibrillation in the next 72 hours

2233.text: are as high as if he's had a STEMI.

2235.text:
Potentially, so we're not
gonna let him go home.

2237.text: He's gonna stay put with us.

2239.text:
Or transfer to a facility that can look
at doing an angio.

2244.text: NORMAN: And how important is that?

2246.text:
Well, I think that... The way again
to think about these patients

2249.text: is not only what risk they're at

2251.text:
but what residual risk can we salvage
in this gentleman.

2253.text:
This is a man who we already
have established has got extensive,

2257.text:
or is at risk of a coronary event,
who's got some ECG changes

2262.text:
and thankfully hasn't got
a positive troponin.

2265.text:
So we know that he's threatening
to have an infarct

2268.text:
and we can potentially prevent
that event from happening

2270.text:
with some judicious use
of anti-thrombotic therapies early on

2276.text:
and transfer for angiography and
definitive revascularisation

2285.text:
In the first instance,
dual platelet therapy

2293.text: Well, we have several cardiac markers

2299.text:
One is BNP that might already be
available in some places.

2303.text:
BNP is much more associated
with left ventricular dysfunction

2307.text:
and therefore is useful for assessing
breathlessness.

2310.text:
There are other markers such as
ischaemia-modified albumin

2314.text: that are still tools of research.

2316.text:
The important thing to point out
about troponin, though,

2318.text: is that it's not just a marker of risk.

2320.text:
It is a marker that one needs to do
something different,

2323.text:
i.e. this person needs to go
and have an angiogram,

2326.text: needs to have their anatomy defined

2328.text:
and their treatment dictated
based on that anatomy.

2332.text:
And that is where troponin
has really revolutionised

2335.text:
the management
of acute coronary syndromes

2337.text:
because it doesn't just tell us
that we're at risk.

2340.text:
It means that there's other things
that we should do.

2342.text:
And, Peter, I suppose it means
that you're also meaning

2345.text:
that this person doesn't move far away
from a defibrillator.

2351.text:
Yes, I think you're right.
In fact, if he presented this way,

2355.text:
it would be a sensible case made
for having an early consultation

2359.text:
with the cardiologist on call
in Adelaide.

2361.text:
In our case, he's going to have
to come down at some stage.

2364.text:
What are we going to achieve by waiting
six, seven or eight hours in a hospital

2369.text:
even if we don't have any absolute proof
that he's having an acute syndrome?

2373.text:
He's got the risk factor,
he's got defined disease,

2376.text:
he's going to have to have
an angiography

2378.text:
and if we could manipulate the system
to get him to go down early,

2381.text:
before he defines,
that would be sensible

2384.text: rather than just waiting and observing

2386.text:
and waiting for possible
troponin rise where we are.

2389.text:
There was actually a very interesting
study performed by

2394.text:
who looked at whether or not
one should wait a long period of time

2398.text:
and fill the patient up with
lots of dual antiplatelet therapy

2402.text: and heparin and so on and so forth.

2403.text:
NORMAN: Stuff you like so much.
- Exactly.

2405.text:
Or treat them as well but take them
to the cath lab within six hours

2412.text: versus waiting three to five days.

2414.text:
In the group that they waited in,
there was a higher event rate

2419.text:
And if you looked at
when those events occurred,

2421.text:
if you looked at the events that
occurred after the angioplasty,

2424.text:
they were exactly the same
in both groups.

2427.text:
So all the events that occurred
of difference were before

2431.text: so what we're doing when we're waiting

2433.text:
is simply waiting for events to occur
despite the therapies.

2436.text: So if you can, get early intervention.

2438.text:
And things have changed in Cairns,
haven't they, Barry?

2442.text:
You've got intervention
available locally now

2446.text:
Yeah, that's right.
New cardiologist from UK's come over.

2451.text:
They've upgraded
some of the facilities there

2454.text:
so they're able to do PCIs on site
there now

2459.text:
instead of sending to Townsville
or Brisbane as the case was before.

2464.text: So let's go to our second case study.

2474.text: She's not been feeling that well

2476.text: over the last two weeks - tired,

2483.text: and that's what she was doing

2489.text: she smokes about a pack a day

2495.text: She's in a very high risk

2498.text: as Barry and I have discussed before.

2500.text:
She has Indigenous background
which puts her

2502.text: in a significantly high risk group.

2504.text:
It's added to by the fact
that she smokes

2506.text:
and there may be a question
of a late presentation

2510.text:
with having had some odd symptoms
this last week.

2518.text: and depending upon that whole context,

2522.text:
you will then discuss with her
recommendations you would make

2527.text:
and it would be a case of trying
to convince her that she is at risk

2531.text:
and trying to convince her
that she is best

2533.text:
to be able to go somewhere
for further treatment.

2536.text:
So, pain goes away on GTN under the
tongue and her troponin's negative.

2545.text: I would place her into a category

2550.text:
and I personally would want to have her
transported down for urgent assessment.

2557.text:
We do have time, her pain has gone,
her troponin's negative

2561.text:
and therefore the myocardia
isn't damaged at this stage

2566.text:
we would arrange for her
to stay in hospital

2568.text:
and to go down within perhaps
a two-day timeframe

2571.text:
but that would be speeded up
if she had further angina etc.

2577.text:
is not necessarily going to feel
that comfortable in a hospital.

2580.text:
None of us feel comfortable
but if she's from a local community,

2584.text:
she's not necessarily going to be
that happy being in hospital

2587.text:
and then certainly transported
even further away from home.

2590.text:
Yeah, that's right but the point is,
could be a life and death situation

2595.text: and that has to be made clear to her,

2597.text:
that, you know, you're in the right
place to be having a heart attack.

2601.text:
I just said there, Norman, sorry,
that by using the family,

2604.text:
and depending upon
the particular relationships,

2609.text:
often decisions that can be shared
with her permission

2612.text:
and can help to get you
to where you want to go.

2615.text:
Depends very much on dealing
with the appropriate way

2618.text:
that local people
would like to be dealt with.

2620.text:
Yeah, that's right.
There may be some decisions around

2624.text:
the people that she has to talk to
about the surgeries

2628.text:
and whoever goes with her
will have to be someone

2630.text: who they can discuss that decision with

2633.text:
and it's best that it's somebody,
an adult,

2637.text:
an escort who's allowed to make
that decision, can't just be anybody.

2641.text:
Of course, women are often relatively
ignored in this situation.

2646.text:
We believe it's cardiac 'cause
we're doing a program on chest pain.

2649.text:
Absolutely, I think it's a multitude
of factors that contributes to that.

2653.text:
Women often experience
slightly more atypical type symptoms.

2657.text: Their pain, when they do experience it,

2663.text: or if they're often slow to present

2666.text:
because they've got to do the dishes
or the clothes or look after...

2669.text: They're the carers in our community

2671.text:
and they're more often
attending to those tasks.

2674.text:
And with delayed presentation,
their symptoms often resolve

2678.text:
so we know that they often get,
well, I wouldn't say neglected,

2683.text:
but they get overlooked is the view
that probably occurs

2689.text: So, Janine, her chest pain comes back.

2692.text:
And so, she's shipped off to the nearest
town where there's a hospital

2696.text: and by the time she gets there,

2701.text: Let's have a look at her ECG

2708.text:
PETER: The ECG there
shows significant changes

2711.text: in the left part of her chest

2716.text: and it would be very consistent

2720.text: with the angiogram that we saw earlier

2727.text:
DEREK: It's a great thing.
SUE: That's good.

2729.text: PETER: Yes, it means so far...

2732.text:
First of all, we must remember troponin
does take a few hours.

2736.text:
She may well have suffered damage
but it will become obvious

2739.text: in four to six to eight hours.

2741.text:
But either way,
she's got definite marker

2744.text: for us to do something about it.

2746.text:
That will depend upon what facilities
we have at that hospital.

2749.text:
She's been going all day,
she had it this morning

2755.text: she had it again just before she came in

2757.text:
and now, 90 minutes
till she gets into town.

2759.text:
You're well beyond your door-to-needle
time, aren't you, with this woman?

2764.text:
Well, that depends on taking
a very careful history.

2766.text:
It may well be
with dissecting the history out

2769.text:
that we do conclude
that this in fact is a recent event

2773.text:
That would be supported
by her initial troponin

2776.text:
if that was negative
and then remained negative.

2779.text:
Then if we check back six to eight hours
prior to those times,

2785.text:
Reckon she started infarcting
quite recently.

2788.text: I think it's also important to point out

2790.text:
that troponin isn't part
of the thrombolytic algorithm.

2793.text:
We don't wait for a troponin to decide
to thrombolyse somebody.

2797.text:
- So I would hope that we have...
NORMAN: So you treat the ECG.

2799.text:
You would obtain the ECG
and if it showed ST elevation,

2803.text:
then I wouldn't be waiting
the 12 or so minutes

2806.text:
for the troponin to come back,
I'd be getting on and treating it.

2811.text: Her colour's bad even on oxygen?

2815.text: if you have primary PCI available,

2817.text:
which is infrequently the case
in this context,

2823.text:
but nevertheless,
if you don't have PCI available,

2827.text:
then you must do something
and that is thrombolysis.

2829.text:
She may be at risk
certainly if she's sick.

2832.text:
But she's certainly going to be worse
if you do nothing.

2835.text:
The critical thing
with cardiac management

2837.text:
is do something,
something is always better than nothing

2840.text: and what you do is situational.

2842.text:
What's the risk of transferring her
post-thrombolysis?

2847.text:
- You generally have a window...
- Do people die in transit?

2850.text:
Generally speaking, the arrhythmias
of the reperfusion process

2853.text: occur over the first hour after.

2857.text:
and most people would prefer
to transport people beyond that time.

2862.text:
On the other hand,
a properly equipped helicopter

2866.text:
with someone who's connected
to a defibrillator

2869.text:
can do just the same
that we can do on the ground.

2871.text: Perhaps ask Derek what he thinks.

2873.text:
Well, certainly the overall risk
of thrombolysis

2876.text:
and the arrhythmias after that
is relatively low.

2880.text:
So, for example, the French
and Queensland system

2886.text:
of drip-and-ship thrombolysis
in the field,

2891.text: and the risks are not particularly high,

2894.text:
certainly not from a bleeding
point of view.

2896.text:
And as long as you're close
to a cardiac defibrillator,

2898.text: then all of that is fine.

2900.text:
In the country where you might be
somewhat restricted

2905.text: from a resource point of view

2906.text: of not being able to ship everybody,

2908.text:
I try and take the attitude of
thrombolyse them and plan for failure,

2912.text:
i.e. look for whether or not
they're going to reperfuse.

2915.text:
Failed reperfusion is marked
by ongoing chest pain,

2918.text:
hemodynamic compromise and/or a failure
to reduce ST elevation by 50%.

2925.text:
So you've already called out
the transport...

2928.text:
I've warned the transport that we're
going to potentially want them,

2931.text: we repeat the ECG at 90 minutes.

2933.text:
If they've got ongoing pain, they don't
meet the reperfusion criteria,

2936.text: we press the button and on they come.

2939.text:
NORMAN: Peter?
- Yeah, I would agree.

2940.text:
And this is the one benefit with having
an integrated transport

2945.text:
The transport people will discuss
with the assessment doctors

2949.text: either the cardiologist and/or the GP

2951.text:
so it's a coordinated approach taking
into account all those issues.

2956.text:
In Victoria, we haven't got
those networks established.

2959.text:
NORMAN: So you beg a lot?
- We do beg a lot.

2961.text:
It requires... The doctors that
you've got there to pick up,

2964.text:
you're basically sort of trying to look
at your corridors of transport.

2969.text:
No, in Warragul, we're down to Monash
Medical Centre, Southern Health,

2972.text:
so we'll start there and then you work
your way across and see how you go.

2975.text: There's certainly a lot of talk,

2977.text:
the networks are trying to get
themselves up and established.

2980.text:
The South Australian one's
been talked about a lot.

2982.text:
There's 35 emergency departments
all trying to get on the same page

2986.text:
about how we look at getting people
to the best place they can be.

2990.text:
I thought the Victorian system
was the model for the nation?

2995.text:
On the grounds that I might lose my job,
I'm not going to say anything.

3002.text:
You've developed a model of cardiac care
in your community-controlled service.

3006.text:
Yeah, we've combined the phase two
and phase three there.

3011.text:
Phase two is about monitoring
the recovery

3015.text:
and a graded exercise
and education program

3017.text:
and phase three is more about
maintenance and self-management.

3021.text:
We've come up with a program
that does those two things together.

3027.text:
Try to prevent a second event and
getting people back on their feet?

3031.text:
And that's integrated with cardiac
rehabilitation nurses in town?

3034.text:
Yeah, we've set it up so that
it's a collaboration between

3038.text:
the coronary care unit and the cardiac
rehab unit at the local base hospital

3042.text: and the local Aboriginal health service.

3046.text:
They come out
and do similar sort of things,

3049.text:
similar sort of activities they do
at the base hospital

3052.text: and the next step after that,

3054.text:
the recovery phase is we try and ensure
that people are eligible,

3059.text: are signed up for a GP management plan

3061.text:
and that they're monitored
over the next 12 to 18 months.

3065.text:
And, Derek, the evidence is very strong
for cardiac rehab, isn't it?

3068.text:
It certainly is.
Meta analyses would suggest -

3071.text: so, combined studies of several groups -

3073.text:
would suggest about
a 15% to 20% reduction

3076.text:
in the risk of mortality
associated with cardiac rehab.

3079.text:
The big shame in
Australian cardiovascular care

3083.text:
is attendance to cardiac rehab
is somewhere between

3090.text:
So you've done all this hard work
and they die of a second...

3095.text:
And the very sad thing about it is
if you look at the people

3101.text:
and look at their time to arrival
to hospital,

3103.text:
it's no shorter than the person
who arrives with their first event

3107.text: so our education isn't getting through.

3109.text:
- Barry, you want to say something?
- Yeah.

3111.text:
National Heart Foundation statistics
a couple of years ago

3114.text:
was indicating that 93% of Aboriginal,
Torres Strait Islander people eligible

3120.text: didn't attend the cardiac rehab program.

3122.text:
So like everything else,
you're under-treated?

3131.text: Pete or Sue, what do people go home on?

3134.text:
What's the evidence-based treatment
for post-myocardial infarction

3140.text: SUE: Well, did you want to...

3142.text:
NORMAN: You're an ED nurse...
- I'm an ED nurse.

3144.text: I bring them in, I treat them...

3146.text:
It's interesting because
this is another area

3149.text:
that with other companies
I'm involved in

3151.text:
and it's in fact focusing
on this very point

3153.text:
and they've just achieved a consensus
that every person

3156.text: who has an acute coronary admission,

3158.text: at whatever part of South Australia,

3160.text:
were given a standardised information
booklet when they go.

3163.text:
When they're discharged
from metropolitan hospital,

3166.text:
they'll be linked to coordinators
in their home area in the country

3170.text:
and that coordinator who may well happen
to work in a doctor's surgery

3173.text:
will follow the patient and help
to organise local rehabilitation.

3177.text:
But they're on an ACE inhibitor,
aspirin?

3179.text:
ACE inhibitors, statins and aspirin
are the three critical factors.

3183.text:
Clopidogrel,
unless you want to have an operation,

3189.text:
are asked to be on clopidogrel
for all their life

3192.text:
but surgeons,
when they want to operate to remove...

3194.text:
If they haven't got a stent in,
are they still on clopidogrel?

3197.text:
Probably for the first year after that,
they don't always stay on that.

3201.text:
But I understand
the drug-eluting stents -

3203.text: and Derek could answer more precisely.

3205.text: NORMAN: You guys put drug-eluting stents

3207.text:
and committing these people
to this long-acting bloody thing.

3210.text:
It's true that about 60%
of intervention procedures

3213.text:
are associated with drug-eluting stents
in Australia these days.

3216.text:
But I think we need to focus carefully
on the issue.

3221.text:
Firstly, that the rate
of stent thrombosis

3224.text:
which is the chief view
with a drug-eluting stent,

3228.text:
but these patients have a recurrent
event rate of 2% per year.

3232.text:
So more events are going to happen
from other areas

3235.text:
in the coronary vasculature
that require prevention.

3238.text:
NORMAN: It's easy to forget
that you've only treated one little bit.

3241.text: So that's the first thing to say.

3242.text:
The second thing to say
is that for most operations,

3248.text:
Sorry, just on that, that emphasises
the importance of post-cardiac care

3253.text:
because you have not fixed the problem
with a stent.

3255.text:
All we have done
is fix the culprit lesion.

3258.text:
We've not fixed the disease which is
plaque in the coronary vessels

3262.text:
right through the coronary vessel
vasculature.

3267.text:
The prevention... You know,
angioplasty has rarely been shown

3274.text:
aspirin and clopidogrel
that have shown that.

3276.text: That's a large randomised trial which...

3281.text:
But if we turn to the problem
of drug-eluting stents,

3284.text: one has to weigh the risk benefit

3286.text:
of having a recurrent
myocardial infarction

3290.text:
versus the surgical risk of bleeding
in any operation.

3294.text: And most operations are not associated

3297.text:
with a very high rate of bleeding
even with clopidogrel.

3299.text:
It is very much a routine fear
that the surgeons have.

3304.text:
they actually can't quote
their rate of bleeding.

3306.text:
Having said that,
there are certain operations

3310.text:
which clearly are associated
with greater risk of bleeding -

3314.text:
and intra-abdominal operations
are of higher risk.

3319.text: One needs to consult their cardiologist

3321.text:
about what the relative risk
of stent thrombosis is.

3325.text:
But you don't know particularly when
you put in more than one stent

3329.text:
how long you...
whether or not you can stop clopidogrel.

3332.text:
Well, the rate is actually
very, very low

3334.text: for the risk of stent thrombosis.

3341.text:
But we also know the risk of restenosis
as well.

3344.text:
It's the function of the diameter
of the lesion

3349.text:
and the length of the lesion
you've treated.

3351.text:
So in people with very long stents,
the risk is much higher.

3355.text:
So we would be more reticent to let
them stop the clopidogrel and aspirin.

3359.text: In people with a discreet stent,

3361.text:
then I'm actually quite comfortable
to let them discontinue the clopidogrel

3370.text:
but I would always maintain one of those
in the longer term.

3372.text:
So, Peter,
let's just talk about preventing

3375.text:
acute coronary syndrome
in the first place.

3378.text:
40% of GPs are still not using absolute
risk tools. It's extraordinary.

3384.text:
It is and I can't really give you
an adequate answer

3387.text:
'cause I can't speak
on behalf of the people who don't.

3389.text:
I think it is possibly a hangover
from my generation

3392.text: that was brought up without the use

3396.text:
In my day, preventive medication
was an anathema.

3399.text:
You weren't allowed to look at people
from that point of view,

3405.text:
And certainly, with my involvement
with registrars and students

3410.text:
the move is very strongly to emphasise
risk stratification

3413.text: and one of the simple other mechanisms

3416.text:
of evaluating coronary care
in a practice

3420.text:
is to see how many patients
who've had coronary episodes

3423.text: are still on aspirin and clopidogrel,

3424.text: how many diabetics are on aspirin,

3426.text:
how many people have their statins
under four.

3429.text:
So I'm positive that
with the mechanisms we have now,

3434.text:
our computer-based tools that allows me
to extract for my patients

3439.text:
how many people fall into whatever
category that I've just mentioned a few,

3442.text: it leads to a much more open evaluation

3445.text:
and I think there's
a much growing acceptance

3447.text: that trying to prevent the problem

3448.text: is as important as treating the problem

3451.text:
and preventing it occurring again
in those groups.

3454.text:
Derek, there's some evidence that
you actually get a rapid effect

3457.text:
if you put somebody
with a high absolute risk

3459.text: on a statin and an anti-hypertensive.

3461.text:
You actually can get a risk reduction
within days.

3464.text:
That's certainly true, there have been
studies that have looked at

3468.text:
patients having their statins
initiated in hospital

3471.text:
or within days
of their myocardial infarction

3474.text:
and showing whether or not that
reduces recurrent events by 30 days.

3478.text:
We know that their cholesterols drop
reasonably quickly

3483.text:
But the studies have been
a little bit underpowered to demonstrate

3489.text:
but there is a clear trend
towards a benefit

3491.text: in hard clinical end points by 30 days

3494.text:
associated with high-dose statins
early on.

3496.text:
So get in there
with your absolute risk tools

3499.text: and put people on the program.

3506.text:
What are your take-away messages
for the audience?

3508.text:
Probably the first thing is to
recognise, I think that's critical,

3511.text:
you can't treat or assess
if you don't keep your mind open

3514.text:
to recognise that chest pain
presentations may be cardiac

3518.text: because an awful lot are not classical.

3523.text:
whatever you have evaluated, we've
discussed different levels of reaction

3527.text:
depending upon
what we're presented with.

3529.text:
The next thing is then put into place
to either rescue or rectify the process.

3533.text: So we have to follow it up.

3537.text: if you want to use the word 'follow up'

3539.text:
or 'rectify' that problem
into the future.

3544.text:
I would agree. If you're experiencing
chest pain and you're not too sure,

3548.text: get to the hospital, get help.

3551.text:
And if you are referred
to cardiac rehab,

3555.text: come along because we can help you.

3557.text:
NORMAN: And you're living proof of it.
- I am.

3562.text:
NORMAN: We didn't get round to that
but we're glad to have you.

3567.text:
I think I'd like people to acknowledge
that the sooner they get to a facility

3572.text:
where we can investigate and initiate
some sort of management,

3577.text:
And that hospitals
and rural health services

3581.text: to try and keep these pathways going.

3585.text:
We don't all have the benefit
of having someone like Derek

3587.text:
sitting in our backroom
that we can call on.

3589.text:
So we need to establish networks with
other regional and tertiary hospitals

3593.text:
to make sure that our clients have
the best possible outcome they can.

3598.text:
My take-home message is act. We've spent
lots of clinical trial resources

3603.text:
looking at the question of fibrinolysis
versus primary PCI

3606.text:
and we've established that PCI
might be slightly better.

3610.text: But for every life that we save

3612.text:
by giving a person PCI
over fibrinolysis,

3614.text:
we would save five lives
if we could get people treated

3621.text:
And we would save
another seven times those lives

3624.text:
if we could actually extend fibrinolysis
to the population of people

3629.text:
who currently don't get it
in Australia today.

3631.text:
Particularly those in the community
which means

3635.text:
with ambulance officers
being properly trained in giving it.

3638.text:
Thank you very much, it's
been a fascinating lively program.

3641.text: I hope you agree with that,

3642.text:
this program on chest pain
and acute coronary syndrome.

3646.text:
Our thanks to the
Department of Health and Ageing

3648.text:
for making this program possible
but thanks also to you

3651.text:
for taking the time to attend
and contribute.

3653.text:
If you're interested in obtaining
more information

3655.text:
about the issues raised in the program,
there are a number of resources

3659.text:
available on the Rural Health
Education Foundation website,

3668.text:
don't forget to complete
and send in your evaluation forms.

3671.text: I'm Norman Swan. I'll see you next time.
